bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, July 2, 1940

div1.p: Hench details his work on the yellow fever story. He asks for Truby's recollections, particularly concerning Lazear's case of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, July 2, 1940
div1.opener:
Y F.
July 2, 1940
General A. E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Washington and Jefferson College is dedicating a memorial building
to Dr. James Lazear this next Fall. Lazear went to this college. The president of
the college, a friend of mine, asked me to prepare a history of Walter Reed and the
work of the Yellow Fever Board. I have been working on this now for three years, and
have done much work, visiting some of the survivors of these experiments. I visited
Kissinger at his home, and I also had him up here, trying to straighten out the story.
I also visited Moran in Havana two months ago, spending about ten days there, and
visited General Kean in Washington, and others. I have learned much, and have found
many new things which have never been published before. I also have uncovered numer-
ous unimportant, and a few rather important errors in the official record. I am
writing this report up in some detail, and will send you a copy as soon as I can.

Among other things, I discovered that the Cuban government has
put a memorial fence and sign on the supposed site of Camp Lazear, and the Secretary
of War already has plans to erect a memorial on this site, which the government bought.
To make a long story short, they have picked the wrong site, and Moran and I were
able, after considerable trouble, to straighten it out, discovering the original
site of Camp Lazear.

The point that I am particularly anxious to have your help in,
however, concerns the question of Dr. Lazear's own case of yellow fever. You, of
course, know the official story that, having been bitten by experimental mosquitoes
which failed to infect him, he was later bitten by a stray mosquito while feeding
his own experimental mosquitoes on yellow fever patients in Los Annis Hospital, later
developing yellow fever spontaneously, not experimental yellow fever, from which he
died. I first heard suspicious that this official story was not true through Moran.
He told me emphatically that it was decidedly understood by those in close connection
with the experiments that Lazear's yellow fever was just as experimental as Carroll's
but for some personal reason the story was allowed to stand. I next learned from
Dr. Agramonte's daughter that her father had told her many times that Dr. Lazear
had deliberately allowed himself to be bitten, perhaps against the advise and wishes
of Dr. Reed, in his zeal to settle the matter, and that be in truth had experimental,
not accidental, yellow fever. It was her understanding that the official story was
allowed to stand because it had something to do with a pension or something. I
broached this subject on a recent visit to General Kean, and he smiled and said some-
thing to this effect, “Oh, you have heard that, too, have you? Well, so far as I know
it is true, although I only knew it two years ago. I think that General Truby may
be able to give you the direct information you wish.” And it is with his permission
that I am writing you.

General Kean and the others with whom I have discussed this
matter, agree with me that after those many years it can do no harm, and can do
much good to at last tell the true story. Depending on the way I shall write it
up, I am sure that I will be able to cast no reflections on Dr. Reed for allowing
the other version to stand. As a matter of fact, he did it at the special request
of Dr. Lazear himself. I know of no more fitting time nor place to give the true
version than on the occasion of a ceremony dedicating a memorial to Dr. Lazear.
Washington and Jefferson is planning quite a celebration, with distinguished med-
ical men from Washington and elsewhere, and it will be quite a dignified and
impressive affair. I sincerely hope that you agree with General Kean and me,
and will be willing to tell me the story in as much detail as possible.

In order to save you the labor of writing this, I shall be only
too glad to have you call a public stenographer or some secretary whom you know,
and dictate to her in as much detail as you possibly can, what you know of this
story. If you will ask her to make a couple of extra carbon copies, I shall be
glad to pay whatever charges she makes.

I should appreciate taking the liberty of writing you later
about other details of the story, When I get my report completed, I will send you
a copy of the various photographs I have taken and the various ones I have obtained
from Dr. Agramonte's dauther, the Army Medical Museum, and others. These will
concern some of the details of the experiments and also the re-discovery of Camp
Lazear. I am sure it will be of great interest to you, and I know that undoubtedly
you will have many comments to make which will be extremely helpful.

As you may know, the Cuban government has been making deliberate
attempts to minimize the work of Reed and the Board, and a great attempt to show
that Finlay deserves all the credit. It is high time that the story be retold
as authentically as possible, without, of course, in any way minimizing the great
contribution of Dr. Finlay.

Can you tell me whether Mrs. Lazear is still living in California?
I am most anxious to get in touch with her and her relatives.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
